{"step_by_step_thinking": "Infectious diseases are caused by pathogens such as bacteria, viruses, fungi, or parasites. Communicable diseases are a subset of infectious diseases that can be transmitted from person to person. Measles, mumps, and scarlet fever are all infectious diseases that are also communicable, as they can be spread from person to person. Tetanus, on the other hand, is an infectious disease caused by a bacterium found in soil, dust, and manure. It enters the body through a wound or cut, but it is not communicable as it cannot be spread from person to person.", "answer_choice": "D"}
